modules.description: This module builds and queries a vantage point tree for efficient nearest neighbor and range searches in a metric space. It supports operations like creating a tree with specified quality, finding nearest neighbors, retrieving points within a tolerance, and checking tree validity. It works directly with point data structures provided by the parameter module, requiring a proper metric for distance calculations.

This module defines the interface for points used in a vantage-point tree, including a distance function to compute metric distances between points. It works with any type `t` that supports a distance metric adhering to the triangle inequality. Concrete use cases include representing spatial points and calculating distances for nearest-neighbor searches in metric spaces.

This module organizes data in a vantage-point tree for efficient nearest-neighbor and range queries in arbitrary metric spaces. It builds hierarchical structures from point data, enabling fast similarity searches, clustering, and distance-based filtering. The core API supports tree construction, nearest-neighbor lookups, and range queries, while the point interface defines distance metrics that ensure correctness under the triangle inequality. Example uses include searching high-dimensional vectors or geographic coordinates with customizable distance functions.

This module offers array creation, transformation, and manipulation capabilities with support for in-place operations, handling both one-dimensional and two-dimensional arrays through functions like mapping, folding, sorting, and shuffling. It integrates with lists, sequences, and matrices while enabling tasks like statistical analysis, data processing pipelines, and algorithmic operations requiring element-wise computation or structural modification. Key features include indexed transformations, predicate-based filtering, and randomized operations such as bootstrapping and shuffling.

This module combines hierarchical data organization for efficient similarity searches with robust array manipulation capabilities. It supports building and querying vantage-point trees for nearest-neighbor and range operations in metric spaces, alongside creating, transforming, and analyzing one- and two-dimensional arrays with in-place and functional operations. Key data types include tree structures for spatial queries and arrays for numerical and algorithmic processing, with operations such as mapping, filtering, sorting, and distance-based search. You can use it to perform high-dimensional vector searches, cluster data points, process statistical datasets, or implement custom algorithms with precise control over data layout and transformation.
